group_siblings.title: View Masters

results.title: Paragon stereoviewer
results.brief_description: Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.
results.description:
Three-dimensional images have been around for more than 180 years – they just weren’t called ‘3D’. Stereoscopic images are two separate pictures with slightly different perspectives. A stereoscopic viewer mimics how we see so that the two images converge into a single three-dimensional picture.

British inventor Charles Wheatstone discovered this process in 1838 and used a device as big as a table to make it work. Another British scientist, David Brewster, later simplified and shrank the viewer into a portable, hand-held device.

Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.
description_for_label:
Three-dimensional images have been around for more than 180 years – they just weren’t called ‘3D’. Stereoscopic images are two separate pictures with slightly different perspectives. A stereoscopic viewer mimics how we see so that the two images converge into a single three-dimensional picture.

British inventor Charles Wheatstone discovered this process in 1838 and used a device as big as a table to make it work. Another British scientist, David Brewster, later simplified and shrank the viewer into a portable, hand-held device.

Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.

results.title: Hungry Horace for ZX Spectrum
results.creator_credit: Melbourne House, Psion Software and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Hungry Horace offered gameplay based of the popular arcade game Pac-Man. It was celebrated as the first arcade game for the Spectrum. It was one of the few Spectrum games that were also available in ROM format. It formed part of the Horace series, which included Horace Goes Skiing and Horace and the Spiders and the unpublished Horace to the Rescue.

Horace is a blue blob with arms and legs, who wanders around a maze, picking the flowers, collecting fruit and avoiding the park guards, who are out to capture him. He is able to momentarily scare the guards, making them vulnerable, by ringing a bell in the maze. If Horace is able to escape capture and leave the maze, he moves to the next, more challenging level.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/hungry-horace-orginal-spectrum/

Last accessed: 17/05/2021

Original game developed by Beam Software and Psion Software. Published in 1982 by Melbourne House.

results.title: Emulation of Hungry Horace for ZX Spectrum
results.brief_description:
Hungry Horace offered gameplay based of the popular arcade game Pac-Man. It was celebrated as the first arcade game for the Spectrum. It was one of the few Spectrum games that were also available in ROM format. It formed part of the Horace series, which included Horace Goes Skiing and Horace and the Spiders and the unpublished Horace to the Rescue.

Horace is a blue blob with arms and legs, who wanders around a maze, picking the flowers, collecting fruit and avoiding the park guards, who are out to capture him. He is able to momentarily scare the guards, making them vulnerable, by ringing a bell in the maze. If Horace is able to escape capture and leave the maze, he moves to the next, more challenging level.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/hungry-horace-orginal-spectrum/

Last accessed: 17/05/2021

Original game developed by Beam Software and Psion Software. Published in 1982 by Melbourne House.

results.title: From Jean-Paul Sartre to Teresa Teng: Cantonese Contemporary Art in the 1980s
results.creator_credit: Clair Hsu, Jane DeBevoise, Siren Films and Arts Asia Archive
results.brief_description:
Interviews with leading Cantonese artists and their memories of a developing art scene in the 1980s.

“The 1980s was a seminal period in the history of contemporary art in China. However, the contribution and experimentalism of the art scene in South China, in particular, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, have generally been overlooked. Due to the proximity of Hong Kong, western ideas from translated books and articles, as well as popular culture in the form of TV shows and Canto pop, flooded over the border to Guangdong at the end of the Cultural Revolution. This influx of new ideas and popular culture sparked great excitement, debate and experimentation in the arts.

Based on primary research, rare film footage and personal interviews with key artists, this documentary bears witness not only to the reading fever that gripped the Chinese art world in the 1980s, but also highlights the experimentalism and verve of artists and critics in South China whose contributions to the development of contemporary art have been long lasting and fundamental.” Source: Arts Asia Archive [www.aaa.org.hk]

Interviewees include: Chen Shaoxiong, Chen Tong, Deng Jianjin, Feng Yuan, Hou Hanru, Huang Xiaopeng, Li Zhengtian, Lin Yilin, Shao Hong, Wang Du, Wang Huangsheng, Xu Tan, Yang Jiechang and Yang Xiaoyan.
results.title_for_label: From Jean-Paul Sartre to Teresa Teng: Cantonese Contemporary Art in the 1980s
results.creator_credit_for_label: Clair Hsu, Jane DeBevoise, Siren Films and Arts Asia Archive
results.description:
Interviews with leading Cantonese artists and their memories of a developing art scene in the 1980s.

“The 1980s was a seminal period in the history of contemporary art in China. However, the contribution and experimentalism of the art scene in South China, in particular, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, have generally been overlooked. Due to the proximity of Hong Kong, western ideas from translated books and articles, as well as popular culture in the form of TV shows and Canto pop, flooded over the border to Guangdong at the end of the Cultural Revolution. This influx of new ideas and popular culture sparked great excitement, debate and experimentation in the arts.

Based on primary research, rare film footage and personal interviews with key artists, this documentary bears witness not only to the reading fever that gripped the Chinese art world in the 1980s, but also highlights the experimentalism and verve of artists and critics in South China whose contributions to the development of contemporary art have been long lasting and fundamental.” Source: Arts Asia Archive [www.aaa.org.hk]

Interviewees include: Chen Shaoxiong, Chen Tong, Deng Jianjin, Feng Yuan, Hou Hanru, Huang Xiaopeng, Li Zhengtian, Lin Yilin, Shao Hong, Wang Du, Wang Huangsheng, Xu Tan, Yang Jiechang and Yang Xiaoyan.

results.title: Hi 5: It's a Hi 5 Christmas
results.creator_credit: Gary Newhnam, Russell Burton, Ian Munro, Alisa Smeaton, Nine Films and Television and Kids Like Us
results.brief_description: A Hi5 Christmas extravaganza! The usual features of a Hi5 television program with the bonus of a live Christmas concert performed in front of an audience at the Sidney Myer Music Bowl in Melbourne. Can be viewed by pressing Play or by selecting the profiles for each group member: Charli, Nathan, Kathleen, Tim or Kellie. Includes “Body move”, “Shapes in space”, “Puzzles and patterns”, “Making music” and “Word play”. Suitable for very young children or early primary school age. Created by Helena Harris and Posie Graeme-Evans.

results.title: What women want
results.creator_credit: Nancy Meyers, Matt Williams, Gina Matthews, Bruce Davey, Susan Cartonis, Centropolis Effects, Wind Dancer Productions, Paramount Pictures and ICON
results.brief_description: Nick Marshall (Mel Gibson) is a real ladies man. Raised by his mother, a Las Vegas showgirl, he has a somewhat distorted perception of what women really want, and an enormous ego. When he is passed over for an executive position in the advertising agency for a woman his chauvinistic attitude worsens. A freak accident while trying to brainstorm ideas for a new advertising campaign, leaves Nick with the ability to hear what women think. Amazed by his new talent Nick seeks the help of a therapist (Bette Midler) who suggests he think of it as a gift and not a curse, and to use this to his advantage. Nick sets his sights on Darcy McGuire (Helen Hunt), the new creative director in the agency. At first his plan works, and he undermines Darcy at every opportunity, until he realises Darcy has feelings for him, and that he feels the same way about her. Cast also includes Marisa Tomei, Mark Feurstein, Lauren Holly, Valerie Perrine, Delta Bourke and Alan Alda

results.title: The Matrix [DVD]
results.creator_credit: The Wachowskis, Andrew Mason, Joel Silver, Warner Bros Pictures and Groucho II Film Partnership
results.brief_description: The Question that drives us all - What is the Matrix? “Do you believe in fate?” “No, I don’t like to know that I am not in control of my life” “You feel that something is wrong but you don’t know what it is. The world that has been pulled over your eyes, that is to blind you to the Truth. I am offering you “The Truth” - nothing more”. These are the questions at the beginning of a film which stretches the imagination, makes you contemplate your own reality and sense of self. Just like Alice in Wonderland following the white rabbit, so too do we follow Neo (Keanu Reeves) to a new and different reality led by Morpheus (Laurence Fishburne). Along this path we meet Trinity (Carrie-Anne Moss), Switch, Cypher (Joe Pantoliano), The Oracle (Gloria Foster) and the ubiquitous Agent Smith (Hugo Weaving), all who assist/interact with Neo to make sense of the original question - What is The Matrix? No-one can conceive it, no-one can be told what it is. It has to be seen to be understood.

results.title: The Silent feminists: America's first women directors
results.creator_credit: Jeffrey Goodman, Anthony Slide and Film Arts Foundation
results.brief_description: This is a history of women directors in Hollywood where, during the silent era, they had a greater presence. With the aid of interviews and film clips, pioneering women in Hollywood such as Alice Guy Blache, Lois Weber and Dorothy Arzner are remembered.

results.title: Frontline. Series 1. Playing the ego card. Add sex and stir. Smaller fish to fry. This night of nights
results.creator_credit: Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, ABC and Frontline TV Prod
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontline”.
Four episodes from the highly acclaimed television series. In “Playing the ego card” Mike wants to boost his credibility and Brook wants the front desk. In “Add sex and stir” Mike has a busy time organising a party and the Frontline team stir up a hot story about lesbianism in sport. Will Mike stick to his guns in “Smaller fish to fry” when he investigates some top businessmen. “This night of nights” takes a look at the Logies.
